image.caption: Image courtesy of the Puerto Rican Cultural Institute
image.name: P000249_001

profileText: a Resident Commissioner from Puerto Rico; born in Bayamon, P.R., August 10, 1882; graduated from Provincial Institute of Puerto Rico in 1897; attended the Keystone State Normal School, Kutztown, Pa., in 1901 and 1902; graduated from the law department of West Virginia University at Morgantown in 1904; admitted to the bar the same year and commenced practice in Puerto Rico; also engaged in agricultural pursuits and dairying; member of the Puerto Rico House of Representatives, 1917-1920; director and president of the Agricultural Association of Puerto Rico; appointed a Resident Commissioner by the Governor of Puerto Rico to the Seventy-Second Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Resident Commissioner Félix Córdova Dávila (April 15, 1932-March 3, 1933); was not a candidate for election in 1932; returned to his law practice and agricultural interests; died in Bayamon, P.R., July 25, 1950; interment in Municipal Cemetery.

asset.name: P000249_001
asset.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Puerto Rican Cultural Institute

note.content: Appointed to fill vacancy caused by resignation of Felix Cordova Davila, and became a member of the House on April 28, 1932.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: "José Lorenzo Pesquera" in Hispanic Americans in Congress, 1822-2012. Prepared under the direction of the Committee on House Administration by the Office of the Historian and the Office of the Clerk, U.S. House of Representatives. Washington: Government Printing Office, 2013.
